title: Output Shaft - Assembly

body.body: The numbers in brackets in the following text refer to the exploded view on
Lubricate each gear and bush with clean engine oil during assembly.
Examine all gears, bearings and sleeves for damage, chipped teeth and wear beyond the service limits.
Replace all components that are not serviceable and always use new circlips, a new output shaft seal and a new sprocket tab washer to assemble the shaft.
Replace all components that are not serviceable and always use new circlips, a new output shaft seal and a new sprocket tab washer to assemble the shaft.
Always wear eye, face, hand protection and overalls when you use a press.
Components can break up when pressed and cause sharp pieces to be thrown at high speed.
Failure to follow the advice above could result in minor to moderate injury.
Make sure that the oil holes in bushes and gears are not aligned with the corresponding oil holes in the input shaft.
If the oil holes are aligned, they oil pressure can be reduced, which will cause premature wear of engine and transmission components
The output shaft bearing and snap ring will be damaged during removal from the shaft and its housing.
Never reuse removed bearings or snap rings as use of damaged or weakened components could cause engine and transmission damage.
Press only on the bearing inner race to prevent bearing damage.

Working from the output sprocket end of the shaft, fit a new bearing (24) and a new sprocket spacer (25) to the shaft using a press and press bars. Fit the sleeve with the large chamfer facing outwards.
Lubricate and fit a new output shaft seal (26).
Transfer the shaft to the vice and secure between soft jaws. Fit the output sprocket (27), new tab washer (28) and nut (29). Tighten the nut to
Withdraw the shaft from the vice and continue to assemble from the opposite end to the output sprocket.
Fit the plain bush (20) to the shaft.
assemble second gear (21) onto the shaft as noted during disassembly, with the large step side facing towards the output sprocket end.
Fit the splined thrust washer (19) and retain with a new circlip (18) as shown below.

Fit sixth gear (17) as noted during disassembly, with the selector fork groove facing away from the output sprocket end. Make sure that the oil holes in the gear do not align with the corresponding oil hole in the output shaft.
Fit a new circlip (16) to retain sixth gear.
Fit the splined thrust washer (15) to the rear of third gear as shown below.
Fit the splined bush (13) for third gear. Make sure that the oil holes in the gear do not align with the corresponding oil hole in the output shaft.
Fit third gear (14) to the shaft with the large step side facing away from the output sprocket.
Fit the splined lock washers (12 and 11). Make sure that the tabs in the smaller washer (11) locate in the slots in the larger washer (12) as shown below.
Fit the splined bush (10) from fourth gear. Make sure that the oil holes in the gear do not align with the corresponding oil hole in the output shaft.
Fit fourth gear (9) as noted during disassembly, with the larger step side facing towards the output sprocket.
Fit the splined thrust washer (8) and retain with a new circlip (7) as shown below.
Fit the fifth gear (6) to the shaft with the groove facing towards the output sprocket. Make sure that the oil holes in the gear do not align with the corresponding oil hole in the output shaft.
Fit the first gear thrust washer (5) and plain bush (4).
When you install first gear, make sure the solid side of the gear faces the clutch.
Fit first gear (3) to the shaft as marked during disassembly as shown below.
Install the thrust washer (2) and needle roller bearing (1) to the end of the shaft.
